flares.note: There is some simultaneous flaring from AR 14294 (S15W30), but the brighter flare is attributed to AR 14299.
Close proximity between AR 14294 and 14296. Appears closer to AR 14294.
Concurrent brightening with AR 14294 that spans about 2025-12-08T22:22Z-T22:46Z in GOES SUVI 131 imagery.

cmes.note: This narrow, faint, jet-like CME is visible to the E/SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. There are two potential sources for this CME which may indicated overlapping CME features of two separate CMEs. However, due to the available viewpoints, it is unclear if there are overlapping CMEs headed to the E/SE in all coronagraphs. The sources include a small filament eruption visible along the E/SE limb in GOES SUVI 304 starting around 2025-12-07T05:00Z with liftoff closer to 2025-12-07T06:00Z, or the more likely source of an area of brightening visible in GOES SUVI 284 starting around 2025-12-07T05:52Z near S10E50 with an area of brightening to the north of it. These two eruptions appear to be sympathetic eruptions and may be magnetically connected to each other.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: Narrow, relatively fast CME seen to the northwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1, not seen in STEREO A COR2 due to poor image quality; the CME does not appear to match any source imagery on the Earth-facing disk, and is thus probably associated with a far-sided source.

cmeAnalyses.note: Leading edge plane of sky measurement using SOHO, as the source longitude is unknown.

cmes.note: Narrow, diffuse CME seen to the northwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 around 2025-12-07T22:00Z; associated with a minor eruption near western limb with northward deflection seen best in GOES SUVI 284 around 2025-12-07T20:48Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Leading edge measurement using approximation of the source based on source EUV imagery

cmes.note: Faint CME first seen to the NNE in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2025-12-08T01:25Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. This CME is not clearly seen in STEREO A COR2. The source of this event is minor field line opening and dimming seen at approx. N50E20 beginning at approx. 2025-12-08T00:24Z as seen in GOES SUVI 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1.

cmes.note: First visible in STEREO A COR2 starting at 2025-12-08T01:38Z already well into the FOV of COR2A following a data gap. The source is most likely associated with an M2.4 flare from AR 14299 that peaked at 2025-12-08T00:12Z and the accompanying eruption beginning around 2025-12-08T00:00Z that is best visible in GOES SUVI 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on fit in STEREO A COR2 with visible source location.

cmes.note: CME first seen to the ESE in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2025-12-08T05:00Z. This CME is also seen to the ESE in SOHO LASCO C3 and GOES CCOR-1. The source of this CME is most likely a small filament eruption from near the SE limb best seen in GOES SUVI 304 starting around 2025-12-08T04:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement to the E (-90 lon.) chosen due to lack of available triangulation.

cmes.note: CME first seen with the bulk to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2025-12-08T05:12Z. This CME is also seen to the NW in GOES CCOR-1 and to the NNE in STEREO A COR2. It is partially obscured by the pylon in SOHO LASCO C3. This CME is most likely related to an X1.1 flare from AR 14298 that peaked at 2025-12-08T05:01Z. The flare and associated eruption are best seen in GOES SUVI 304. The ejecta from the eruption experiences visible northward deflection.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best-fit of widest part of the bulk in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2, and GOES CCOR-1.

cmes.note: CME first seen to the N in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2025-12-08T07:24Z. This CME is also seen to the N in SOHO LASCO C3 and GOES CCOR-1. The front may also be faintly seen for a couple of frames in STEREO A COR2. This CME is most likely associated with an M1.8 flare from AR 14299 that peaked at 2025-12-08T06:54Z. The flare and accompanying ejecta can best be seen in GOES SUVI 304. The ejecta appears to be deflected northward.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best-fit among SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2.

cmes.note: CME first seen to the North by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-12-08T14:40Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1 in later frames. This CME appears to have a much wider half width in STEREO A compared to in SOHO and GOES. The source of this event is an eruption from the vicinity of Active Region 14299 (N21W21), beginning at approx. 2025-12-08T14:00Z as seen in GOES SUVI 195. There also appears to be a channel of dimming that travels to the North of the initial eruption, which suggests a Northward deflection.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1.

cmes.note: Faint CME observed to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1, not observed in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap. The source is likely associated with an M1.2 flare from AR 14299 (N26W30) peaking at 2025-12-08T22:28Z, observed in GOES SUVI 131. Also observed as brightening and field line movement in GOES SUVI 171/195/284.

cmeAnalyses.note: SOHO LASCO C2 and GOES CCOR-1 only analysis, as the CME travels into the LASCO C3 pylon and STEREO A COR2 is in a data gap. Using the flare source at N26W30 (AR 14299) as the source, could vary around W20-W40 and N20-N30.

cmes.note: Faint CME first seen to the West by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-12-08T23:24Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and GOES CCOR-1 in later frames. This CME is not clearly seen in STEREO A COR2. There is no clear source seen for this event, aside from some minor field line movement seen along the Western limb in GOES SUVI 195 beginning at approx. 2025-12-08T22:28Z which may be related.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement using a longitude of +90 degrees due to unclear source location and lack of STEREO A COR2 imagery to triangulate.

cmes.note: CME with a somewhat fuzzy front seen to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2 and GOES CCOR-1, catching up/overlapping with 2025-12-08T23:24Z CME. The corresponding front is likely seen to the NE in STEREO A COR2 starting from 2025-12-09T01:38Z. The front in COR2 is a bit more clear/pronounced than in SOHO and CCOR-1. The source of this CME is not completely clear but might be the eruption and M2.0 flare from Active Region 14299 (N22W25). The CME is seen in C2 a bit earlier than the start of the flare, however the dimming is seen starting prior to the start of the flare.

cmeAnalyses.note: Very approximate analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs (SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2), if we are correct regarding the corresponding fronts.

cmes.note: Extremely faint minor CME seen to the NNW in SOHO LASCO C2 and GOES CCOR-1 and not seen in SOHO LASCO C3. The likely corresponding front in STEREO A COR2 is very faintly seen to the N starting after 2025-12-09T01:53Z. No clear source has been found for this CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate analysis based on the fit of the faint front with two coronagraphs (SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2). No source has been found in EUV imagery to confirm this analysis.

cmes.note: CME first seen to the SW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-12-09T03:00Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3, GOES CCOR-1 and to the SE in STEREO A COR2 in later frames. This source of this event is a minor M1.1 flare from Active Region 14294 (S19E41) which peaked at 2025-12-09T01:38Z. This flare is visible in GOES SUVI 131, along with a narrow curved ejecta seen in GOES SUVI 304, some field line opening and Southeastern stretching dimming seen in GOES SUVI 195, suggesting some Southeastern deflection.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1 and STEREO A COR2.

cmes.note: Very faint, narrow jet-like front seen in difference imagery of SOHO LASCO C2 and GOES CCOR-1 and too faint to be seen in white light imagery and in difference imagery of SOHO LASCO C3. The CME somewhat resembles CME: 2025-12-09T00:12Z but is narrower and fainter. It is not seen in STEREO A COR2. No source for it has been found in EUV imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Since the CME is not seen in STEREO A COR2 coronagraph and no source has been found for it, only plane-of-sky analysis is possible.

cmes.note: Faint CME first seen to the NW by GOES CCOR-1 beginning at 2025-12-09T16:15Z, as well as by STEREO A COR2 in later frames. This CME is not available in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 in real time due to a downlink data gap beginning at 2025-12-09T11:15Z. The source of this event is minor field line opening seen originating from the vicinity of N35W20 beginning at approx. 2025-12-09T15:09Z, exhibiting some Northern deflection as seen in GOES SUVI 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between GOES CCOR-1 and STEREO A COR2.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the SW in GOES CCOR-1 and STEREO A COR2. The CME is not visible in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 due to a data gap starting at 2025-12-09T11:00Z. The source appears to be a filament eruption from beyond the western limb in GOES SUVI 304 starting around 2025-19-09T18:04Z. Moving/opening field lines along the W/SW limb in GOES SUVI 284 starting around 2025-12-09T16:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Preliminary parameters based on best fit using GOES CCOR-1 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: CME first seen to the NE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-12-09T21:42Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and GOES CCOR-1 in later frames. This CME is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap from 2025-12-09T21:38Z to 2025-12-10T02:08Z. The source of this event is field line opening and dimming seen beginning at approx. 2025-12-09T20:48Z located at approx. N20E60 as seen in GOES SUVI 195. Post eruptive arcades are also visible in GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1.

cmes.note: CME first seen to the NNW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-12-09T23:00Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1 in later frames. There is no abundantly clear source for this CME, but some faint field line movement is visible along the North limb tracing back on disk beginning at approx. 2025-12-09T21:36Z in GOES SUVI 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1.

cmes.note: Faint CME first seen to the Northeast in SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-12-10T02:48Z, as well as by STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1 in later frames. The source of this event is field line opening and dimming seen in GOES SUVI 195 beginning at approx. 2025-12-10T01:48Z located at approx. N15E55. This source region is in close proximity to a coronal hole, which may result in some Western deflection.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1.

cmes.note: Narrow CME first seen to the NNW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-12-10T04:36Z as well as by SOHO LASCO C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1 in later frames. The source of this event is an eruption near Active Region 14299 (N22W40) beginning at approx. 2025-12-10T02:44Z as seen by GOES SUVI 195, likely exhibiting some Northwestern deflection.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1.

cmes.note: Very faint CME seem to the NNW in SOHO LASCO C2, GOES CCOR-1 and to the NNE in STEREO A COR2. Its source could be a long-lasting eruption of a filament stretching from N30W40 to N40W30 (centered ~N35W35) seen in the GOES SUVI 195 starting after 2025-12-10T15:00Z. The filament stretches to the NE from AR 4304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate analysis based on the fit with three coronagraphs (SOHO LASCO C2, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1) and confirmed by the likely source centered at N35W35.

cmes.note: Bright CME seen in SOHO LASCO C2 and GOES CCOR-1 to the SW. The start of the CME is covered by the daily gap in STEREO A imagery. The source is the M4.4 class flare from AR 14294 (S17W66). Other coronal signatures are not pronounced: although there is some movement of field lines and the brightening associated with the flare, not much more is seen in GOES SUVI 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Initial, preliminary one-coronagraph (SOHO LASCO C2 and GOES CCOR-1) analysis of this CME based on the source location (S17W66) and on the limited imagery from CCOR-1 and two timestamps of C2 because of expected delay in SOHO imagery.

cmes.note: Faint CME observed to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2, the event is faint in SOHO LASCO C2 before reaching LASCO C3's field of view. The CME is also visible in GOES CCOR-1. The source is likely a small filament eruption centered around S15E58, observed starting around 2025-12-11T00:48Z in GOES SUVI 304, and some brightening and field line movement in GOES SUVI 195/284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulation between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 with only early frames, before the CME front becomes too faint to resolve.

cmes.note: Faint CME observed to the W in STEREO A COR2, and faintly in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1. The source is likely far-sided, observed only in STEREO A EUVI 195/304 around 2025-12-11T02:55Z as field line movement and a post-eruptive arcade on or just beyond the W limb as viewed from STEREO A.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulation between STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1.

cmes.note: CME seen to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2, and GOES CCOR-1. There is no clear source in available EUV imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky measurement using GOES CCOR-1. No STEREO A or SOHO imagery was chosen for this measurement due to poor running difference imagery quality.

cmes.note: Faint CME observed to the W in SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2, the event diffuses before reaching LASCO C3 and GOES CCOR-1 visibility. The source is likely far-sided, visible only in STEREO A EUVI 195/304 as filament ejecta and field line movement on the W limb as viewed from STEREO A.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulation between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 with only early frames, before the CME front becomes too faint to resolve.

cmes.note: Faint CME observed to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2. The source is likely associated with a C5.0 flare from AR 14299 (N26W60) observed in GOES SUVI 131, also observed as filament ejecta flowing out following the flare in GOES SUVI 171/195/284/304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulation between SOHO LASCO C2, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2. LASCO C3 cannot be used as the CME travels into the pylon.

cmes.note: CME visible to the NW in GOES CCOR-1 imagery. Not visible in STEREO A COR2 or SOHO LASCO C2/C3 in real-time due to data gaps. The potential source is a C2.3 flare peaking at 2025-12-11T12:12Z and associated eruption (approximately N20W55), best seen in GOES SUVI 304 imagery. The eruption is also visible in STEREO A EUV imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location using GOES CCOR-1 imagery only in SWPC_CAT.

cmes.note: CME visible to the west in GOES CCOR-1 imagery. Not visible in STEREO A COR2 or SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery in real-time due to a data gap. There was no associated source eruption visible in available EUV imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky measurement using GOES CCOR-1 running difference imagery in SWPC_CAT.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely related to an M2.0 flare from Active Region 14296 (S18W73) starting around 2025-12-12T05:00Z as seen in GOES SUVI 131/171/195/284/304 and STEREO A EUVI 195/304 imagery. Field line movement is observed over the southwest limb in GOES SUVI 171/195/304 imagery and dimming is observed southeast of the eruption site in STEREO A EUVI 195 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is a C8.6 flare and subsequent eruption from Active Region 14296 (S20W89) starting around 2025-12-13T10:40Z which exhibits a southern deflection as seen in GOES SUVI 131/171/195/284/304 and STEREO A EUVI 195/304 imagery. An opening of field lines is seen over the southwest limb at this time in GOES SUVI 195/284 imagery and dimming is observed south of the eruption site in STEREO A EUVI 195 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the source location, accounting for visible southern deflection, and the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: Faint CME first seen to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2 starting around 2025-12-13T21:12Z part way into the FOV. CME is also seen to the SE in SOHO LASCO C3 and GOES CCOR-1. There is no definitive source for this CME on the Earth-facing disk but could be related to some very minor activity and fluctuation across the SE quadrant visible for several hours prior to the CME start time. This CME is much easier to see in running difference imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement chosen due to lack of available chronograph triangulation and lack of definitive source candidate.
